even numbers (= 2, 4, 6, etc.)
odd numbers (= 1, 3, 5, etc.)
You owe me 27 dollars? Make it 30, that's a good round number.

senses.definition: used before a figure to show the position of something in a series

examples.x: They live at number 26.
The song reached number 5 in the charts.

senses.definition: a set of figures that is used to identify something or communicate by phone, etc.

examples.x: Ask for the customer's name and phone number.
Customers can reach us by calling an 0800 number (= a free phone number in the UK).
I'm sorry, I think you have the wrong number (= wrong phone number).
Call this number and ask to speak to John.
What is your account number, please?
Can I have your credit card number?
Please give your landline and mobile phone numbers.

senses.definition: a quantity of people or things

examples.x: A large number of people have applied for the job.
In a small number of cases the illness is fatal.
The number of homeless people has increased dramatically.
The total number of students has doubled in the last six years.
Huge numbers of (= very many) animals have died.
A number of (= some) problems have arisen.
I could give you any number of (= a lot of) reasons for not going.
Use a pedometer to count the number of steps you take.
Our aim is to reduce the number of road accidents.
This year we have increased the number of events from six to ten.
We were eight in number (= there were eight of us).
Nurses are leaving the profession in increasing numbers.
Sheer weight of numbers (= the large number of soldiers) secured them the victory.
The course will have to be repeated owing to pressure of numbers (= too many students).
staff/student numbers

senses.definition: a group or quantity of people

examples.x: one of our number (= one of us)
The prime minister is elected by MPs from among their number.

senses.definition: the version of a magazine, etc. published on a particular day, in a particular month, etc.

examples.x: the October number of ‘Vogue’
The back numbers of ‘The Times’ were kept in a basement.

senses.definition: a song or dance, especially one of several in a performance

examples.x: They sang a slow romantic number.

senses.definition: a thing, such as a dress or a car, that is admired

examples.x: She was wearing a black velvet number.

senses.definition: the form of a word, showing whether one or more than one person or thing is being talked about

examples.x: The word ‘men’ is plural in number.
The subject of a sentence and its verb must agree in number.

senses.definition: following a set of simple instructions identified by numbers

examples.x: painting by numbers

senses.definition: following closely the accepted rules for doing something
an easy job; a pleasant situation that other people would like

examples.x: It’s all right for him—he’s got a very cushy number.

senses.definition: to do something that will harm somebody/something, especially when it feels like it is done deliberately, from a desire to hurt (even if this is not actually the case)

examples.x: Throat cancer did a number on me a few years ago.
The Covid-19 pandemic did a number on global stock markets.

senses.definition: to know what somebody is really like and what they plan to do

examples.x: He thinks he can fool me but I've got his number.

senses.definition: the time has come when you will die or lose everything
a way of considering an activity, etc. that considers only the number of people doing something, things achieved, etc., not with who or what they are

examples.x: MPs were playing the numbers game as the crucial vote drew closer.

senses.definition: a person who does the same job as you in another organization

examples.x: The Foreign Secretary is currently having talks with his opposite number in the White House.

senses.definition: being in a group makes you safer and makes you feel more confident
being in a group gives you more power

examples.x: There's strength in numbers, so encourage your friends and family to join us.

senses.definition: the combined power, strength or influence of a group

examples.x: They won the argument by sheer weight of numbers.

senses.definition: to give a number to something as part of a series or list

examples.x: All the seats in the stadium are numbered.
I couldn't work out the numbering system for the hotel rooms.
Every paper was carefully numbered and indexed.
The coins are individually numbered.
Each pigeonhole is clearly numbered by floor and by room.
Park your car on the even-numbered side of the street.
Number the car's features from 1 to 10 according to importance.
The doors were numbered 2, 4, 6 and 8.

senses.definition: to make a particular number when added together

examples.x: The crowd numbered more than a thousand.
We numbered 20 (= there were 20 of us in the group).
The African student population in France currently numbers nearly 8,000.

senses.definition: to include somebody/something in a particular group; to be included in a particular group

examples.x: I number her among my closest friends.
He numbers among the best classical actors in Britain.

senses.definition: a person or thing will not continue to live, exist or be successful for much longer

examples.x: His days as leader of the party are numbered.
Whatever the protests, the school’s days are numbered and it will be closed down.

senses.definition: existing in large numbers

examples.x: He has been late on numerous occasions.
The advantages of this system are too numerous to mention.
I tried numerous times to talk to Chris.
Numerous studies have shown this to be true.
Dr Malcolm has won numerous awards.
The related publications are far too numerous to list individually.
She wrote numerous articles on social issues.
He claimed that he could provide numerous other examples of her incompetence.

senses.definition: a person whose job is to take care of sick or injured people, usually in a hospital

examples.x: a registered nurse
a qualified/trained nurse
She trained as a nurse in Korea.
student nurses
a male nurse
a dental nurse (= one who helps a dentist)
a psychiatric nurse (= one who works in a hospital for people with mental illnesses)
a team of doctors and nurses
a nurses' station (= an office for nurses in a hospital)
Nurse Bennett
Nurse, come quickly!
I work as a nurse in a busy hospital.

senses.definition: (in the past) a woman or girl whose job was to take care of babies or small children in their own homes
a place where young children are cared for while their parents are at work; a day nursery or nursery school

examples.x: Her youngest child is at nursery now.
The children are at nursery three days a week.

senses.definition: a room in a house where a baby sleeps
a room in a house where young children can play
a place where young plants and trees are grown for sale or for planting somewhere else
the job or skill of caring for people who are sick or injured

examples.x: a career in nursing
nursing care
the nursing profession

senses.definition: a small hard fruit with a very hard shell that grows on some trees

examples.x: to crack a nut (= open it)
a cashew nut
a hazelnut
nuts and raisins
chopped nuts
She is allergic to nuts.
She has a severe nut allergy.
a nut roast/cutlet

senses.definition: a small piece of metal with a hole through the centre that is screwed onto a bolt to hold pieces of wood, parts of machines, etc. together

examples.x: to tighten a nut
a wheel nut
a jar full of nuts and bolts

senses.definition: a person’s head or brain
an offensive word for a person who you think is strange or crazy
a person who is extremely interested in a particular subject, activity, etc.

examples.x: a fitness/tennis/computer nut

senses.definition: a man’s testicles
to become very angry

examples.x: She’ll do her nut when she finds out!

senses.definition: a person who is difficult to deal with or to influence
a difficult problem or situation to deal with
the basic practical details of a subject or an activity

examples.x: The documentary focuses on the real nuts and bolts of the film-making process.

senses.definition: crazy
to use more force than is necessary
the process by which living things receive the food necessary for them to grow and be healthy

examples.x: advice on diet and nutrition
to study food science and nutrition
Nutrition information is now provided on the back of most food products.

senses.definition: food that is needed to grow and be healthy

examples.x: A feeding tube gives her nutrition and water.
